history.content:
Took 61a , 54, and ee16a last semester and got A/A-'s. Taking 61b and 70 this semester, and it is significantly harder for me mainly because of CS 70.

However, since you have taken the IMT decal and are familiar with discrete math, you'll be more than ready for 70. Also, i also had some Java experience going into 61b, and the class has been really easy for me.

children.subject: And because I’ve heard of the immense length of his projects

Oh forgot to mention — Have Hug for 61B and Rao and Ayazifar for 70. And to clarify IMT is a big factor for the reason why I said I was familiar with discrete math; prior to that I only sort of knew a bit about the concept of math tricks/etc associated with proofs.
To above responder, thanks for your input! Surprised to hear that 61b’s been going easy for you since you have hillfinger.
You'll be fine. Taking 61b+70 together is pretty common so as long as you work hard and keep up with lectures and projects you'll do well.

I would like to finally respond. The reason is because my alternatives for classes don’t look good either:
1) CS61B, EE16B, 53: involves stress of studying over break although I myself think the studying is doable. 53 I already have prior knowledge of, but as for EE I’m spending time studying a topic which I’m not even interested in pursuing in the future, so not helping me get a job
2) CS61B, EE16A, 53: I know the material for 2 out of three classes already, so it’s boring.
I’ll also only be taking 61B and 70 for 2 technicals

Before putting yourself in that position, I think you should ask yourself, how come you want to declare super early by sophomore year? Are you trying to rush into upper division classes? If you want to do research, do you need A+s in those classes, even though they're lower division classes? Essentially, what I'm trying to get at is, even though you may very well be able to declare and tackle both classes together, what else could you be doing had you taken the classes separately? Since you're applied math also, will you be able to balance out whatever other math class on top of 61B and 70?

history.content:
Wanted to hear anyone's thoughts about what 61B+70 spring was like after 61A+54 fall. I'm having an easy semester and think that 61A and 54 is an easy workload (i.e. I'm relaxing a good amount this semester), heading towards As in both classes. I'm aiming to get ~A-/A in both 61B and 70.

I’m CS+math(applied math major or pure math minor tbd depending on future plans with cs courses/grad courses), hence the decision to take 54, but I realize that I should’ve taken 16a too this semester due to the content overlap.

Specifically I would like to hear from people who did the following same path of courses from fall to spring. Please include your coding background and math experience, and transition of grades from fall to spring. I'm looking towards having a successful semester next semester and want to do what I can to ensure that.

I have Java experience and am familiar with discrete math through taking the IMT decal this fall. 

For additional context, my high school friend did the same path as me and has affirmed that the rigor of the math at our high school prepared us for 70. I didn’t ask him what grades he got in the classes though.

Thanks!
history.subject: CS 61B and CS 70
